metadata.titel_preek: Advent: The Absence of God and the Coming of the Light

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God (the Master) returns to a household (the Church) currently experiencing His absence and the world's darkness, to judge and establish a new creation.

tekstueel_bewijs: It is he who put the whole operation in motion
He will come in the future... as the King in his glory
A power from outside is coming... able to make a new creation

object.identificatie: Salvation / New Creation / The Kingdom of Heaven
tekstueel_bewijs: to make a new creation out of people like us
the kingdom of heaven is at hand

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The 'Advent Clock' (Divine Necessity)
tekstueel_bewijs: The witness is from God; the light is from God
people who have no capacity of ourselves to save ourselves

helper.identificatie: John the Baptist / The Holy Spirit / Grace
tekstueel_bewijs: It is God’s power that gives good deeds

tegenstander.identificatie: The Powers of Darkness / Sin / Human Inability / The World's Calendar
tekstueel_bewijs: no capacity of ourselves to save ourselves
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but 'the whole frame of this world' and 'the absence of God'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer, having received power, bears fruit and reorients their life.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer / The Church
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Fruit of Repentance / Solidarity with others
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is explicitly stated as a result of the primary program (God's power).

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: John the Baptist → God → Powers of Darkness

voorbeelden_god_subject: He will come in the future
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we must cast away the works of darkness
we will become less interested in receiving personal blessings

voorbeelden: he must not find us asleep
we will become more and more thankful
the Advent clock tells the church what time it is
I need power from outside myself to make me different
The power that is coming is not our power

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon acknowledges the 'Devoir' (Must) but identifies human 'Inpouvoir' (Inability), locating the solution in the 'Pouvoir' (Power) of God.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Absence/Darkness) through ~S1 (Self-righteousness) to S1 (Grace/Power).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'One Who Comes' who bridges the gap between judgment and life.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; the 'axe at the root' and 'darkness' are presented as real threats.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon explicitly rejects human capacity and locates the agency of change in an external divine power.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Keep awake, then … if he comes suddenly, he must not find you asleep.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: I need power from outside myself to make me different.
It is God’s power that gives good deeds... We are able to repent and bear fruit because he is coming.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: John the Baptist is explicitly de-emphasized as an example and re-cast as a 'witness' or 'spotlight' pointing to Christ.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: John the Baptist (rejected as primary focus)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: John is a signpost for God's action, not a model for human effort.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-transformation; vigilance based on hope rather than fear.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic sanctification (God as the primary mover in the believer's life).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Master's absence' to 'God's power' is seamless and logically consistent.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'Stay awake' (Command) and 'No capacity' (Inability).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: the kingdom of God is in head-on collision with the powers of darkness

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Total inability; sin is a darkness and a collision of powers.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a masterclass in theocentric narrative structure. God is the Subject of all transformative verbs.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly heavy on Devoir (Must) in the first half.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: The second half corrects this by grounding Devoir in Pouvoir.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Ensure the 'Keep awake' command is always heard as a response to the 'Master's coming' rather than a condition for it.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon avoids the trap of moralism by explicitly stating that even the 'will' and 'ability' to repent are gifts from the coming God.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'darkness' imagery; Greimas shows that the darkness is an actantial Opponent that only God can defeat.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Matthew 3; Greimas shows how the preacher reassigns the 'Subject' role from John/Hearer to God.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'spotlight' metaphor for John the Baptist is a semiotic move to prevent the hearer from making John the Subject/Hero.

volledige_subject_lijst: God (established, gathered, assigned, put in motion, gave shape, returns, judges, gives power)
The Church (watches, waits, takes a beating, repents [by power], bears fruit [by power])
appendices.notities: The sermon follows Fleming Rutledge's grammar of grace perfectly.
